message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest an allergic reaction, possibly to the latex condom used during intercourse. Oral cetirizine, an antihistamine, can be used to relieve pruritus and other symptoms of an allergic reaction. Acyclovir is used to treat viral infections, which is not the cause of the patient's symptoms. Cromolyn sodium and famotidine are used to treat asthma and gastroesophageal reflux disease, respectively, which are not the cause of the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest an allergic reaction, possibly to a latex condom or a detergent used to wash it. Oral cetirizine is an antihistamine that can help alleviate allergic reactions. Intravenous acyclovir is used to treat viral infections, which is not indicated in this case. Oral cromolyn sodium and famotidine are used to treat different types of gastrointestinal conditions, which are not relevant to this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the patient’s history suggest an allergic reaction. Oral cetirizine, an antihistamine, is the appropriate next step in management. Intravenous acyclovir is used to treat viral infections, while oral cromolyn sodium and oral famotidine are used to treat allergic disorders such as asthma and ulcers respectively.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the patient has developed an allergic reaction to something, and the history of an itchy rash around his mouth after blowing up balloons further supports this. The most appropriate next step in management would be to administer an antihistamine such as oral cetirizine to help relieve the itching associated with the rash on his penis. Intravenous acyclovir would be used to treat a viral infection such as herpes, which is not suggested by his symptoms. Oral cromolyn sodium and oral famotidine are used to treat allergies or acid reflux respectively, but are not the most appropriate next step in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and history suggest an allergic reaction, possibly to latex. Cetirizine is an antihistamine that can help manage the allergic reaction. Acyclovir is for herpes simplex virus infection, but there are no vesicular lesions. Cromolyn sodium and famotidine are for asthma and heartburn, respectively, and are not appropriate for this situation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and history suggest an allergic reaction, possibly to latex. Oral cetirizine, an antihistamine, is the most appropriate next step in management to help alleviate the symptoms of the allergic reaction. Intravenous acyclovir, oral cromolyn sodium, and oral famotidine are not indicated for an allergic reaction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest an allergic reaction, and among the options, only oral cetirizine is an antihistamine used to treat allergic reactions. Intravenous acyclovir is used to treat viral infections, which is not suggested in this case. Oral cromolyn sodium is used to treat mast cell-mediated diseases, which is not the root cause in this case. Oral famotidine is used to treat stomach ulcers and gastroesophageal reflux disease, which is not suggested in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest an allergic reaction, possibly to latex. Oral cetirizine, a histamine blocker, can help relieve symptoms of allergic reactions. Intravenous acyclovir is used for herpes simplex virus infections, which is not suggested by the patient's symptoms. Oral cromolyn sodium and oral famotidine are not indicated for an allergic reaction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, including the pruritic rash and previous history of balloon-related rash, suggest a contact dermatitis or allergic reaction. Cetirizine, an antihistamine, is the most appropriate next step in management. Acyclovir is used for viral infections, while cromolyn sodium and famotidine are not indicated for allergic reactions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and history suggest an allergic reaction, possibly to latex as the patient developed an itchy rash after blowing up balloons 2 years ago. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer oral cetirizine, an antihistamine that relieves allergic symptoms including itching and redness. Intravenous acyclovir is used to treat viral infections such as herpes simplex virus. Oral cromolyn sodium is used to prevent asthma attacks and allergic reactions, but not to treat acute symptoms. Oral famotidine is a histamine-2 receptor antagonist that is used to treat conditions such as gastroesophageal reflux disease and peptic ulcer disease, but is not indicated in this scenario.
